policy_type: Property Host Insurance - Short-term rental/hosting insurance (30 Days policy)
coverage_summary: Insurance for property hosts renting their property to guests for short-term stays (up to 30 days). Covers damage to buildings and contents caused by guests or visitors during valid bookings, including accidental damage, malicious damage, theft, fire, water escape, and liability to others. Also covers loss of income following a claim, electric vehicle charging points, and legal expenses.
key_inclusions: Accidental damage to buildings and contents by guests/visitors
Theft or attempted theft by guests/visitors
Escape of water or heating oil from tanks, equipment or pipework
Loss or theft of keys and lock replacement
Alternative accommodation if property uninhabitable (up to £200/day)
Kennelling costs for host's animals (up to £50/day)
Alternative accommodation for guests if property uninhabitable (up to £150/day)
Loss of income following a claim (up to £10,000)
Electric and hybrid vehicle charging unit damage
Host liability to third parties (up to £5,000,000)
Pest infestation fumigation costs due to guests
Fatal bodily injury to host at premises (up to £10,000)
key_exclusions: Cosmetic damage (scratches, marks, dents not affecting functionality)
Damage caused by the host themselves
Domestic pet damage (chewing, scratching, tearing, fouling)
External walls or roofs of flats/apartments and communal areas
Claims where deposit exceeds or equals the claim value
Claims from bookings made after the host knew of potential claim
Claims where Property Policy would cover
Theft without police report and crime reference number
Valuables and electrical valuables over £5,000 per item
Theft of valuables not kept in locked safe/locked room
Laptops, tablets, phones not kept locked when unattended
Guns, sports equipment, scuba diving equipment
Any claims over policy limits specified per section
special_conditions: Must have existing valid annual Property Policy in place
Property Policy provider must be informed of hosting activity within 30 days
Cover must be in place before guests arrive
Must have written agreement with guest (or verbal agreement for family/friends)
Maximum 20 people (10 adults/10 children) at any one time
Must operate in compliance with local authority regulations and laws
Must provide adequate instruction to guests on property use
Property must be well maintained and in good repair
Property must be equipped with essential items (curtains, beds, furniture)
No renovations or structural alterations during guest stays
Valid gas safety certificate required if applicable
Must comply with fire safety regulations
Host must take reasonable precautions to prevent loss
Property must be free of tripping/slipping hazards
Must report theft/malicious damage to police immediately
Must obtain crime reference number for theft/malicious damage claims
Claims must be reported within 30 days of discovery
Must retain full guest deposit
Multiple incidents during one Valid Booking treated as single claim with single excess
Valuables must be kept in locked safe or locked room inaccessible to guests
Laptops, tablets, phones must be locked away when unattended
excess_deductible: £100 excess applies to most claims. Specific excess amounts: Fire/Smoke/Explosion - £100; Accidental/Malicious Damage - £100; Theft - £100; Emergency Services - £100; Key Loss - £100; Contents claims - £100; EV Charging Points - none specified; Liability - £100. First amount payable on every claim for which the insured is responsible.
geographical_coverage: United Kingdom (including Northern Ireland), excluding Channel Islands. Legal Expenses also covers Isle of Man and Channel Islands for legal advice.
age_restrictions: Not explicitly stated in the document
pre_existing_conditions: Not applicable for this property insurance type
cancellation_policy: 14-day cooling-off period from date of purchase or receipt of documents (whichever is later) for full refund unless claim made or incident likely to result in claim. After 14 days: no refund and all outstanding premiums become due. Insurer can cancel with 14 days' notice for valid reasons (non-payment, threatening behavior, failure to provide documents, non-compliance with terms). If insurer cancels, refund provided less charge for cover already provided (except fraud cases).

endorsements.name: Section 1a - Buildings - Insured Property
endorsements.description: For properties that are NOT flats/apartments. Covers full building structure including fixtures, fittings, garages, outbuildings, driveways, gardens, swimming pools, solar panels, wind turbines.
endorsements.coverage_impact: Provides higher limits than Section 1b: £1,000,000 for fire/water escape vs £50,000 for flats; £80,000 for accidental/malicious damage vs £50,000 for flats

endorsements.name: Section 1b - Buildings - Flat/Apartment Structures
endorsements.description: For flat/apartment properties. Covers fixtures, fittings, internal walls and doors (including entrance door from communal area). Does NOT cover external walls, roofs, or communal areas.
endorsements.coverage_impact: Lower coverage limits than Section 1a. Excludes external walls, roofs, and communal areas which are building management responsibility

endorsements.name: Section 2 - Contents
endorsements.description: Covers household items, valuables, electrical valuables and personal belongings inside the property, garages, outbuildings and gardens. Excludes motorised vehicles, charging points, documents, domestic pets.
endorsements.coverage_impact: Adds coverage for movable property. Sub-limits apply for valuables (£20,000 total, £5,000 per item)

endorsements.name: Section 3 - Loss of Income
endorsements.description: Covers loss of hosting income if property uninhabitable due to repairs from successful claim under Sections 1a, 1b or 2.
endorsements.coverage_impact: Up to £10,000 per claim. Excludes first 14 complete days after insured event. Only covers bookings made before the insured event.

endorsements.name: Section 4 - Electric and Hybrid Home Charging Units
endorsements.description: Covers damage to EV charging points at the insured premises caused by guests/visitors or hosting activity.
endorsements.coverage_impact: Up to £1,500 per claim. Excludes incorrect use by host, improper installation/maintenance, non-compliance with regulations

endorsements.name: Section 5 - Your Liability to Others
endorsements.description: Covers legal liability for accidental property damage or bodily injury to third parties/guests/visitors arising from hosting activity including charging point use.
endorsements.coverage_impact: Up to £5,000,000 including legal costs. Major exclusions: host/family/employees/permanent residents injury, professional business liability, certain animals, vehicles, pollution, food/drink provision, theft/damage to guest property, sporting equipment, swimming pools

endorsements.name: Section 6 - Legal Expenses
endorsements.description: Covers legal costs for contract disputes, repossession of guests, personal injury by guests/visitors, and tax enquiries related to hosting activity.
endorsements.coverage_impact: Up to £50,000 per claim. Includes 24/7 legal and tax advice helpline. Must have reasonable prospects of success. Minimum £100 claim value. Covers: contract disputes, guest eviction, personal injury, HMRC tax enquiries

claims_requirements.notification_timeframe: Must contact insurer as soon as reasonably possible and in any event no later than 30 days from discovery of incident or event that might lead to claim. For theft/malicious damage: must inform police immediately upon discovery.
required_documents: Full details of loss or damage
Evidence of ownership (receipts, purchase documents, instruction manuals, guarantee cards, valuations, photographs)
Proof that guest/visitor damage occurred during Valid Booking
Pre and post letting inspection reports
Police crime reference number (for theft/malicious damage)
Evidence of deposit retained from guest
Proof of payment received from guest for the booking
For Legal Expenses: any claim forms, application notices, legal documents, correspondence from other parties
process_steps: Contact insurer within 30 days of discovery
For theft/malicious damage: report to police immediately and obtain crime reference number
Provide policy name and number when notifying claim
Complete claim form with full details
Take reasonable steps to minimize loss and prevent further damage
Do not dispose of damaged items or carry out permanent repairs until instructed
Do not abandon property to insurer
Obtain estimates for repair/replacement if requested
Allow insurer access to damaged property for inspection
Cooperate fully with insurer and provide requested information
For liability claims: send all claim forms, legal documents, correspondence immediately
For liability claims: do not admit/deny responsibility or make agreements with third parties
Retain full deposit paid by guest
Provide evidence guest has paid for the booking
For Legal Expenses: report claim as soon as aware of circumstances that could lead to claim
claims_requirements.evidence_requirements: Proof of ownership via receipts; proof that guest/visitor damage occurred during Valid Booking (booking records, letting history, inspection reports); police crime reference number for theft/malicious damage; estimates for repairs; photographs of damage; deposit retention evidence; proof of guest payment; booking agreement documentation
claims_requirements.claims_contact: 24 Hour Claims Line: 0800 032 7327; Online (non-urgent): www.prestigeunderwriting.co.uk/claims; Post: Prestige Underwriting, 4th Floor, Lanyon Building, North Derby Street, Belfast, BT15 3HL. For Legal Expenses claims: ARAG Tel: 0117 917 1698 or download claim form at www.arag.co.uk/newclaims

eligibility_criteria.medical_restrictions: Host or permanent residents must never have been cautioned for, convicted of, or charged with any criminal offences (other than spent convictions and motoring offences)
eligibility_criteria.residency_requirements: Must be UK or Isle of Man resident (excludes Channel Islands). Property must be located within UK (including Northern Ireland).
other_restrictions: Must be property owner or have legal responsibility for the property
If tenant: must have written permission from landlord to act as host
No more than 2 property/host insurance claims in last 12 months
No more than 3 property/host insurance claims in last 5 years
Property must be well maintained in good repair and not undergoing renovation
Property not Grade 1 listed (England/Wales) or Grade A listed (Scotland/NI)
Property must not have thatched or part-thatched roof
Property rebuild value must be less than £1,000,000
Maximum 20 people (10 adults/10 children) at property at any one time
Must have existing Property Policy in place
Must inform existing property insurer within 30 days about hosting activity
Must operate in compliance with local authority regulations and laws
Must agree to provide/permit access to letting history including Platform data
No building/renovation works during guest stays
Valid gas safety certificate required if applicable

policy_definitions.Valid Booking: A property rental booking for a Guest for an agreed period of time
policy_definitions.Guest: (a) Person(s) including their family/travelling companions who the host has agreed may stay at the insured premises for agreed period as set out in written short let agreement; (b) Family or friends who the host has agreed may stay without charge
policy_definitions.Visitor: Person(s) present at insured premises due to invitation/actions of Guest and not included in the written short let agreement
policy_definitions.Host: Person(s) or company named on policy schedule who have agreed to allow Guests onto their property
policy_definitions.Hosting Activity: Any activity performed to fulfil host's legal obligations under terms of written short let agreement, or verbal agreement for family/friends, for agreed period at insured premises
policy_definitions.Insured Premises: The Insured Property or Flat/Apartment Structure owned by policyholder or for which they are legally responsible and let with landlord's permission by host and registered with insurer under policy
policy_definitions.Contents: Household items including valuables, electrical valuables and personal belongings inside insured premises (including garages, outbuildings, gardens) which policyholder legally owns or is responsible for. Excludes motorised vehicles, charging points, documents, domestic pets
policy_definitions.Valuables: Jewellery and watches, precious gems, stones, bullion, gold and silver plated articles, precious metals, furs, pictures, paintings, works of art
policy_definitions.Electrical Valuables: Tablets, laptops, phones, home computers, monitors, satellite decoders, audio and video equipment
policy_definitions.Deposit: Amount collected by host from guest intended to cover potential loss or damage caused by guest during their Valid Booking
policy_definitions.Accidental Damage: Accidental sudden and unintentional loss or destruction of or damage to the host's property
policy_definitions.Malicious Damage: Any act of intended damage to the insured premises or its contents
policy_definitions.Theft: Any act of fraud or dishonesty committed with clear intent of obtaining improper financial gain
policy_definitions.Bodily Injury: Death or physical injury caused by sudden and unexpected external visible event
policy_definitions.Charging Point: Hybrid or electric vehicle charging unit (including connections and cables) at insured premises
policy_definitions.Loss of Income: Amount of monetary benefit host would have received from guest for hosting activity excluding amounts payable to third parties such as fees or commission
policy_definitions.Property Policy: Property insurance policy including cover for damage when not used for hosting activity, covering perils such as: flood, storm, landslip, heave, subsidence, escape of water, fire, smoke, theft, together with liability to others cover
policy_definitions.Reasonable Costs: Costs for goods and services which are competitive in the relevant marketplace
policy_definitions.Excess: The first amount of each and every claim for which policyholder is responsible
policy_definitions.Family: Husband, wife, partner, civil partner (person living with them as though married), children (including adopted and foster children), and any other immediate family
policy_definitions.Period of Insurance: The period shown on policy schedule as Period of Insurance
policy_definitions.Platform: Any website which connects the guest with the host
policy_definitions.Communicable Disease: Any disease transmissible by any substance/agent from any organism to another where: (1) substance/agent includes virus, bacterium, parasite or other organism or variation thereof; (2) transmission method includes airborne, bodily fluid, surface/object, solid/liquid/gas, or between organisms; (3) disease can cause/threaten damage to human health/welfare or property. Includes Covid-19, any coronavirus strain, and any pandemic or non-pandemic disease

time_sensitive_requirements.waiting_periods: Loss of Income: 14 complete days after insured event (no cover for first 14 days)
time_sensitive_requirements.notification_deadlines: Claims must be reported within 30 days of discovery. Theft/malicious damage must be reported to police immediately upon discovery
time_sensitive_requirements.claims_deadlines: Must report within 30 days of discovery. Later reporting may result in claim rejection or reduced settlement
time_sensitive_requirements.cooling_off_period: 14 days from date of purchase or receipt of policy documents (whichever is later). Full refund unless claim made or incident likely to result in claim occurred

common_questions.question: Do I need another property insurance policy to have this cover?
common_questions.answer: Yes, you must have a valid annual Property Policy in place during the period of insurance. This policy is designed to work alongside your existing property policy as additional insurance for hosting activities. You must inform your property policy provider within 30 days about hosting activity.
common_questions.section_reference: Eligibility section and General Policy Conditions

common_questions.question: What is a Valid Booking and why is it important?
common_questions.answer: A Valid Booking is a property rental booking for a guest for an agreed period of time. This is critical because cover must be in place before guests arrive, and at the time of any loss/claim the property must be subject to a Valid Booking. Without a Valid Booking, claims will not be covered.

common_questions.question: Will my claim be covered if the guest paid a deposit?
common_questions.answer: Claims are not covered where the deposit paid by the guest is greater than or equal to the value of the claim. You must have retained the full deposit paid by the guest. If the deposit exceeds the policy excess, the amount exceeding the excess will be deducted from the claim settlement.
common_questions.section_reference: General Claims Exclusions and How much we will pay

common_questions.question: What do I do if a guest steals something or causes malicious damage?
common_questions.answer: You must immediately report the theft or malicious damage to the police and obtain a crime reference number. Then report the claim to the insurer within 30 days. Claims for theft or malicious damage without a police report and crime reference number will not be covered.
common_questions.section_reference: General Claims Conditions and What is not Covered sections

common_questions.question: Are there limits on valuable items?
common_questions.answer: Yes. Individual valuables and electrical valuables are limited to £5,000 per item. The total for all valuables and electrical valuables is limited to £20,000 per claim. Valuables must be kept in a locked safe or locked room inaccessible to guests, or theft claims won't be covered.
common_questions.section_reference: Section 2 - Contents, What is not Covered

common_questions.question: Does this cover COVID-19 related claims?
common_questions.answer: No. The policy explicitly excludes any loss, damage, claim, liability, cost or expense arising from or relating to Communicable Disease, which is specifically defined to include Covid-19, any other type or strain of coronavirus, and any other pandemic.

common_questions.question: What if my property is uninhabitable after a claim - will this policy help?
common_questions.answer: Yes. The policy will pay for reasonable costs of alternative accommodation for you and your family (up to £200/day, max £20,000), kennelling of your animals (up to £50/day, max £5,000), and alternative accommodation for guests who were staying (up to £150/day, max £5,000). It will also cover cancellation charges up to £200 for subsequent bookings.

common_questions.question: Will I be compensated for lost rental income?
common_questions.answer: Yes, under Section 3 if the property is uninhabitable due to repairs following a successful claim. However, there's a 14-day waiting period (no cover for first 14 complete days), and only bookings made before the insured event are covered, up to £10,000 total.
common_questions.section_reference: Section 3 - Loss of income following a claim

common_questions.question: What's the difference between the buildings cover for houses versus flats?
common_questions.answer: Section 1a covers Insured Property (houses) with higher limits: £1m for fire/water, £80k for accidental/malicious damage. Section 1b covers Flat/Apartment Structures with lower limits: £50k for fire/water and accidental/malicious damage. Importantly, for flats, external walls, roofs, and communal areas are NOT covered.

common_questions.question: Am I covered if a guest injures themselves at my property?
common_questions.answer: Yes, Section 5 provides liability cover up to £5,000,000 for accidental bodily injury to guests, visitors or third parties arising from hosting activity. However, there are significant exclusions including injury from certain animals, vehicles, swimming pools, food/drink provision, and criminal/violent acts.

common_questions.question: What if a guest damages my electric vehicle charging point?
common_questions.answer: Section 4 covers damage to charging points caused by guests/visitors or hosting activity up to £1,500. However, it doesn't cover damage from incorrect use by you, improper installation/maintenance, or non-compliance with regulations.
common_questions.section_reference: Section 4 - Electric and Hybrid Home Charging Units

common_questions.question: Can I cancel this policy and get a refund?
common_questions.answer: You have 14 days from purchase or receipt of documents (whichever is later) to cancel for a full refund, unless you've made a claim or had an incident. After 14 days, there's no refund and all outstanding premiums become due.

common_questions.question: What is NOT covered under this policy?
common_questions.answer: Major exclusions include: cosmetic damage; wear and tear; damage by domestic pets or vermin; damage during professional cleaning; damage you cause; renovations; sewage blockages; communicable disease; terrorism; war; computer viruses; claims without Valid Booking; claims where deposit equals/exceeds claim value; claims over specified limits; claims not reported to police (theft/malicious damage).
common_questions.section_reference: General Policy Exclusions and section-specific What is not Covered

common_questions.question: Who can I contact for legal advice about my hosting activity?
common_questions.answer: The policy includes a 24/7 Legal and Tax Advice helpline on 0344 571 7978. Legal advice is available 24/7, tax advice 9am-5pm weekdays. This covers personal legal matters including hosting activity within UK, Isle of Man, Channel Islands and EU law, plus personal tax matters within UK.

common_questions.question: How quickly do I need to report a claim?
common_questions.answer: You must contact the insurer as soon as reasonably possible and in any event no later than 30 days from discovery of any incident or event that might lead to a claim. For theft or malicious damage, you must report to police immediately. Late reporting may result in claim rejection or reduced settlement.
common_questions.section_reference: How to Make a Claim and General Claims Conditions
